question.context: A command and control behavior was blocked on host `vnevado-win10r`, which indicated an active infection by malware that could replicate and receive commands from remote attackers. This malware was active, and precautionary measures should be taken to check for residual signs of infection. The process involved had the ID 1332 and ran the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com`.
question.question: What is the IP address associated with the Manatee Tempest activity group detected in this security incident?
solution: The account with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` was involved in a Command and Control behavior that was blocked.
The cybercriminal group known as Manatee Tempest, which is associated with the IP address `198.43.121.209`, was active during the incident.

Contact your incident response team, or contact Microsoft support for investigation and remediation services.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"54ad0689-8fab-409e-86fd-2956ecd657e5","MitreTechniques":"T1047","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}'), ('2024-06-20 09:44:54.449914+00:00', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

", 'vnevado-win10r.vnevado.alpineskihouse.co', have been victimized by ransomware. There is no guarantee that handing over the ransom will give you access to your files again. Paying the ransom could also make you a target for more malware.

•	Contact your incident response team.
NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic investigation. A forensic investigation is important to identify Indicators of Compromise (IoC) that may be used to prevent other machines from installing the malware.
•	Check if files on the affected machine were encrypted by ransomware.
        o	If files were encrypted, disconnect the machine from the network as soon as possible.
•	Check for other suspicious events in the machine timeline.
•	Check for the observed deleted file name or SHA1 on other machines in the network.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email)
•	Rebuild the affected machine.
•	After the affected machine has been rebuilt: 
         o	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
         o	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
         o	Configure your Trust Center to disable macros.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"ca3d4939-c0fe-4a2f-8ebd-48a0ac00e0aa","MitreTechniques":"T1490","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}'), ('2024-06-20 09:44:53.793994+00:00', 'Suspicious remote activity', 'Suspicious activity initiated remotely was observed on this machine. Contact your incident response team, or contact Microsoft support for investigation and remediation services.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"64e1767d-3cc3-4573-8707-d2892b79c155","MitreTechniques":"T1021;T1047;T1105;T1569.002","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}'), ('2024-06-20 09:44:53.716588+00:00', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', Contact your incident response team, or contact Microsoft support for investigation and remediation services.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"54ad0689-8fab-409e-86fd-2956ecd657e5","MitreTechniques":"T1047","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}'), ('2024-06-20 09:40:00.779383+00:00', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', question.context: An incident involving a ransomware payload remotely launched on device `vnevado-win11u` with AadDeviceId `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e` and IP address `99.83.111.100` has been detected. The attackers might be attempting to encrypt content on this device. Additionally, there is a notable change in typical user behavior that may indicate a compromise.
question.question: What is the command line of the suspicious process involved in the user behavior change on device `vnevado-win11u`?
solution: A ransomware payload was remotely launched by the user with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` at `2024-07-04 22:35:03.038773+00:00`.

Suspicious hands on keyboard user behavior was detected on this device, involving a process with Process ID `88` launched with the command line `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com` at `2024-06-20t09:29:42.3927529z`.

question.context: A Mimikatz credential theft tool was detected on a device at 2024-07-04 22:35:03.797541+00:00. Mimikatz is a tool used to harvest plaintext passwords, password hashes, smartcard PINs, and Kerberos tickets. The attacker might be leveraging this tool to harvest credentials to log into this or other devices on the network by impersonating a valid user. Several command line executions involving `mimikatz.exe` were observed, along with connected mimikatz-related files like `mimidrv.sys`, `mimispool.dll`, and `mimilove.exe`. More information can be found in the Mimikatz tool profile Threat Analytics report and the Actor profile: Storm-0875 Threat Analytics report provided by Microsoft.
question.question: Can you identify the IP address involved in the malicious credential theft tool execution detected?
solution: The Mimikatz credential theft tool was detected on the device with IP address `107.224.99.179`.
A malicious credential theft tool execution was detected on the same device with IP address `107.224.99.179`.

trajectory.action:
SELECT 
    t.table_schema, t.table_name, c.column_name, c.data_type
FROM information_schema.tables t
JOIN information_schema.columns c
  ON t.table_schema = c.table_schema AND t.table_name = c.table_name
WHERE t.table_schema NOT IN ('information_schema','mysql','performance_schema','sys')
  AND (
      c.column_name LIKE '%process%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%command%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%image%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%alert%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%event%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%ip%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%source%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%device%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%host%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%time%' OR
      c.column_name LIKE '%timestamp%'
  )
ORDER BY t.table_schema, t.table_name, c.ordinal_position

SELECT 
  DeviceId,
  DeviceName,
  TimeGenerated,
  Timestamp,
  ProcessCommandLine,
  InitiatingProcessCommandLine,
  LocalIP
FROM env_monitor_db.DeviceProcessEvents
WHERE TimeGenerated BETWEEN '2024-07-04 22:34:30' AND '2024-07-04 22:35:30'
  AND (
    LOWER(ProcessCommandLine) LIKE '%mimikatz%' OR
    LOWER(ProcessCommandLine) REGEXP 'mimi(dr|spool|love)\\.(sys|dll|exe)' OR
    LOWER(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) LIKE '%mimikatz%' OR
    LOWER(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) REGEXP 'mimi(dr|spool|love)\\.(sys|dll|exe)'
  )
ORDER BY TimeGenerated

  AND (

  AND (LOWER(sa.AlertName) LIKE '%mimikatz%' OR LOWER(sa.Description) LIKE '%mimikatz%')

question.context: During a recent investigation involving potentially compromised assets exhibiting ransomware-like behavior, it was observed that an attacker might be using the specified user account, IP, or device to move laterally across the network. Some of the files involved are `syncretic.7z.lockbit`, `earlap.doc`, `ponceau.7z`, and `unstreaming.xlsx.lockbit`. The suspicious activities were noted on the host `vnevado-win11u`, with associated account SID `S-0-6-5`. Automated remediation actions might be taken to disable the account or device being used by the attacker.
question.question: Can you identify the hostname of the device where system recovery setting tampering was observed?
solution: The user with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` is potentially compromised and exhibiting ransomware-like behavior, affecting multiple devices.

System recovery settings have been tampered with on the device with hostname `vnevado-win10s`, which could indicate an attempt by adversaries to disable system recovery features and prevent system recovery.

trajectory.action: SHOW TABLES

SELECT DISTINCT dpe.DeviceName AS Hostname, dpe.InitiatingProcessAccountSid, dpe.FileName, dpe.ProcessCommandLine, dpe.Timestamp
FROM DeviceProcessEvents dpe
WHERE (
    dpe.FileName IN ('vssadmin.exe','vssadmin','wbadmin.exe','wbadmin','bcdedit.exe','bcdedit','wmic.exe','wmic','powershell.exe','cmd.exe','reg.exe','reg')
    AND (
        dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%delete shadows%'
        OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%shadowcopy%'
        OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%shadow copies%'
        OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%bcdedit%recovery%'
        OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%disable%recovery%'
        OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%SystemRestore%'
        OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%srservice%'
        OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%wbadmin%delete%'
    )
)
OR (
    dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%vssadmin delete shadows%'
    OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%bcdedit /set {default} recoveryenabled No%'
    OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%bcdedit /set recoveryenabled No%'
    OR dpe.ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%wbadmin delete%'
)
ORDER BY dpe.Timestamp DESC
LIMIT 100

trajectory.action:
SELECT
  TimeGenerated,
  ActivityGroupNames,
  ThreatType,
  Description,
  NetworkIP,
  NetworkDestinationIP,
  NetworkSourceIP,
  DomainName,
  Url
FROM ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
WHERE ActivityGroupNames LIKE '%Manatee Tempest%'
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC
LIMIT 50

SELECT a.TimeGenerated, a.AlertName, a.Description, a.Severity
FROM SecurityAlert a
WHERE a.Description LIKE '%Manatee Tempest%' OR a.AlertName LIKE '%Manatee Tempest%'
ORDER BY a.TimeGenerated DESC
LIMIT 50
SHOW COLUMNS FROM SecurityAlert

SELECT TimeGenerated, AlertName, AlertSeverity, Description, ExtendedProperties, Entities
FROM SecurityAlert
WHERE Description LIKE '%Manatee Tempest%' OR AlertName LIKE '%Manatee Tempest%'
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC

[('2024-06-20 09:44:54.449914+00:00', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'High', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

('2024-06-20 09:40:00.779383+00:00', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'High', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

question.context: A recent security incident involved the tampering of system recovery settings on the device `vnevado-win10r`. The process `vssblatemp.exe` was executed with the command `vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all`, indicating an attempt to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may include deleting all volume shadow copies to impede system restoration.
question.question: Alongside the usage of `vssblatemp.exe`, another process was used to disable recovery features. What was the command and process ID of the other process involved?
question.answer: Command: bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no, Process ID: 4312
solution: System recovery setting tampering has been detected on this device.
The adversary used the command `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` with Process ID `4312` on `2024-06-20t09:10:48.0676225z` to disable automatic Windows recovery features.

question.context: A security incident involving system recovery setting tampering was observed on a device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options. The process `vssblatemp.exe` was executed with the command to delete all volume shadow copies, and the process `bcdedit` was used to disable automatic Windows recovery features.
question.question: What is the host name of the device involved in this tampering incident?
solution: Potential tampering of system recovery settings observed on host `vnevado-win10s`. Adversaries might use utilities like vssblatemp.exe, wmic, wbblatemp.exe, or bcdedit.exe to disable or delete system recovery features.

question.context: A possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected on the host `vnevado-win10s` involving user with username `dp5hn`. The PRT is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication used to enable single sign-on (SSO) across applications on supported devices, and attackers attempting to access this resource could be aiming for lateral movement or credential theft. The attempt was carried out by the process `browsercore.exe` as observed from the process ID `2676`.
question.question: Related to this alert, there was an active malware detected subsequently. Can you identify the name of the malware file detected on the machine?
solution: There was a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) through the process `browsercore.exe` detected on 2024-07-04.
Another possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected involving the account with SID `S-5-7-21-1843151660-3234030288-105586167-1422`.
Active unknown malware, specifically `mimikatz.exe`, was detected and running on the machine.

trajectory.action: SHOW TABLES

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessAccountName, FileName, ProcessCommandLine, ProcessId FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE DeviceName='vnevado-win10s' AND InitiatingProcessAccountName='dp5hn' AND FileName='browsercore.exe' AND ProcessId=2676 ORDER BY Timestamp ASC LIMIT 10

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessAccountName, FileName, ProcessId, ProcessCommandLine FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE DeviceName='vnevado-win10s' AND LOWER(FileName)='browsercore.exe' ORDER BY Timestamp ASC LIMIT 50

SELECT sa.TimeGenerated, sa.AlertName, sa.Description, sa.SystemAlertId, sa.Severity, sa.CompromisedEntity FROM SecurityAlert sa WHERE (sa.Description LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' OR sa.AlertName LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' OR sa.Description LIKE '%PRT%' OR sa.Description LIKE '%browsercore.exe%' OR sa.AlertName LIKE '%PRT%') AND sa.CompromisedEntity LIKE '%vnevado-win10s%' ORDER BY sa.TimeGenerated ASC

trajectory.observation:
[('2024-06-20 09:19:23.604535+00:00', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Medium', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

[('2024-06-20 09:19:23.521302+00:00', "'CommandAndControl' malware was detected during lateral movement", 'Medium', "'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on this device. An attacker might be attempting to move laterally to this device from another device on the network.", '6b033b86-3938-d3b6-cd72-34a3509dcb85'), ('2024-06-20 09:19:23.544335+00:00', 'Command and Control behavior was blocked', 'Low', 'Malware and unwanted software are undesirable applications that perform annoying, disruptive, or harmful actions on affected machines. Some of these undesirable applications can replicate and spread from one machine to another. Others are able to receive commands from remote attackers and perform activities associated with cyber attacks.

A malware is considered active if it is found running on the machine or it already has persistence mechanisms in place. Active malware detections are assigned higher severity ratings.

Because this malware was active, take precautionary measures and check for residual signs of infection.', '8d6872d7-0a01-d28d-10f3-f73c8875ff9f'), ('2024-06-20 09:19:23.719343+00:00', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'High', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', '3f25b0c7-fcf6-aee6-7790-0b8e5ba10dd7'), ('2024-06-20 09:19:23.778088+00:00', 'Suspicious remote activity', 'Medium', 'Suspicious activity initiated remotely was observed on this machine. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

question.context: A ransomware payload was remotely launched on a host named `vnevado-win11t` with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`. Attackers might be attempting to encrypt content on this device, rendering it unusable to users. For more information, refer to the Threat Analytics report, Threat overview: Human-operated ransomware: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/05658b6c-dc62-496d-ad3c-c6a795a33c27/analystreport. Soon after, potentially compromised assets began exhibiting ransomware-like behavior, impacting multiple devices.
question.question: What is the name of the file associated with the ransomware-like behavior identified in the potentially compromised assets?
solution: A ransomware payload was remotely launched by the user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
Potentially compromised assets are exhibiting ransomware-like behavior involving the file `syncretic.7z.lockbit`.

3. Review device timelines for suspicious activity that may have occurred around the time of the alert.
4. Look for unfamiliar processes. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.
5. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors.
6. Look for the presence of relevant artifacts on other devices. Identify commonalities and differences between potentially compromised devices.

B. Scope the incident. Find related devices, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.

C. Contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Stop suspicious processes, isolate affected systems, decommission compromised accounts or reset passwords, block IP addresses and URLs, and install security updates.
2. If you believe that the alert is a false positive:
     2.1 A user may have been suspended automatically. Revert the action by enabling the user account through the MDI portal or Active Directory.
     2.2 Devices may have been automatically contained. Revert the action through the device page in the portal.

•	Contact your incident response team.
NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic investigation. A forensic investigation is important to identify Indicators of Compromise (IoC) that may be used to prevent other devices from installing the malware.
•	Check if files on the affected device were encrypted by ransomware.
        o	If files were encrypted, disconnect the device from the network as soon as possible.
•	Check for other suspicious events in the device timeline.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email)
•	Rebuild the affected device.
•	After the affected device has been rebuilt: 
         o	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
         o	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
         o	Deploy the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) utility for behavioral-based exploit prevention.

1. Check if the device owner or IT personnel had a legitimate reason to launch the command.
2. Look for recent signs of activity by the compromised user account or device and investigate them. Make sure to check other devices in your organization, as well as the original device associated with the compromised assets.
3. Review device timelines for suspicious activity that may have occurred around the time of the alert.
4. Look for unfamiliar processes. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.
5. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors.
6. Look for the presence of relevant artifacts on other devices. Identify commonalities and differences between potentially compromised devices.

B. Scope the incident. Find related devices, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.

C. Contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Stop suspicious processes, isolate affected systems, decommission compromised accounts or reset passwords, block IP addresses and URLs, and install security updates.
2. If you believe that the alert is a false positive:
     2.1 A user may have been suspended automatically. Revert the action by enabling the user account through the MDI portal or Active Directory.
     2.2 Devices may have been automatically contained. Revert the action through the device page in the portal.

D. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', have been victimized by ransomware. There is no guarantee that handing over the ransom will give you access to your files again. Paying the ransom could also make you a target for more malware.

•	Contact your incident response team.
NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic investigation. A forensic investigation is important to identify Indicators of Compromise (IoC) that may be used to prevent other machines from installing the malware.
•	Check if files on the affected machine were encrypted by ransomware.
        o	If files were encrypted, disconnect the machine from the network as soon as possible.
•	Check for other suspicious events in the machine timeline.
•	Check for the observed deleted file name or SHA1 on other machines in the network.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email)
•	Rebuild the affected machine.
•	After the affected machine has been rebuilt: 
         o	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
         o	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
         o	Configure your Trust Center to disable macros.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"ca3d4939-c0fe-4a2f-8ebd-48a0ac00e0aa","MitreTechniques":"T1490","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}'), ('2024-06-20 09:44:54.225475+00:00', 'File backups were deleted', 'File backups were deleted', 'High', 'All file snapshots and shadow copies have been deleted via WMI or VSSAdmin which is common during Ransomware infection.

3. Check for other suspicious activities in the device timeline. Identify unusual system activity with system owners. ​

B. Scope the incident. Find related devices, network addresses, and files in the incident graph. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures. ​

trajectory.action:
SELECT DISTINCT
  JSON_UNQUOTE(JSON_EXTRACT(e.value, '$.Name')) AS FileName
FROM SecurityAlert sa
JOIN JSON_TABLE(sa.Entities, '$[*]' COLUMNS (value JSON PATH '$')) AS e
WHERE sa.DisplayName = 'Potentially compromised assets exhibiting ransomware-like behavior'
  AND JSON_EXTRACT(e.value, '$.Type') = 'file'
  AND JSON_UNQUOTE(JSON_EXTRACT(e.value, '$.Name')) IS NOT NULL

question.context: A recent security incident was flagged due to the execution of a known credential theft tool, which was used to dump user's credentials. This was detected on an account from a specific IP address.
question.question: A related alert indicates the presence of a file associated with Mimikatz. Can you identify the name of this file that was detected?
solution: A known credential theft tool execution command line was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
The Mimikatz credential theft tool, particularly the file `mimilib.dll`, was detected on this device.

question.context: There was a detection of unknown malware being active in the environment, which was stopped by Windows Defender but it is recommended to further check the machine for signs of infection. Following that, there were multiple alerts indicating possible attempts to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) which is a key artifact used for Azure AD authentication. Additionally, we observed an alert where system recovery settings were tampered with, indicating that adversaries might be attempting to delete or disable built-in operating system data and recovery services. This could prevent recovery of a corrupted system and denie access to backups and recovery options. Various built-in Windows utilities can be exploited to disable or delete system recovery features, posing a risk to system integrity.
question.question: What is the name of the account involved in the system recovery setting tampering incident?
solution: An unknown malware was detected and was active on the host with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
There was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) involving the process `browsercore.exe`.
The user with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` was involved in a potential attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT).
System recovery setting tampering was observed on the account named `dp5hn`.

[('2024-06-20 09:19:23.499691+00:00', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'High', 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures ('2024-06-20 09:40:00.302895+00:00', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'High', 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]', '[{"$id":"2","ProcessId":"1900","CommandLine":"vssblatemp.exe delete shadows ('2024-06-20 09:44:53.914101+00:00', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'High', 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]', '[{"$id":"2","ProcessId":"1900","CommandLine":"vssblatemp.exe delete shadows question.context: An alert indicated that 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected, suggesting an attempt to move laterally between devices.
question.question: What is the hostname of the target device in the 'CommandAndControl' malware attempt?
solution: The 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the device associated with the account with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`.
The 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the host `vnevado-win11u` during an attempted lateral movement.

trajectory.action: SHOW TABLES

FROM SecurityAlert sa
WHERE sa.AlertName LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR sa.Description LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR sa.AlertType LIKE '%CommandAndControl%'
ORDER BY sa.TimeGenerated DESC
LIMIT 50

question.context: A security incident involving the Manatee Tempest activity group was flagged, where the actor Manatee Tempest, known for its early malware campaigns like the Dridex banking trojan, has been active since June 2014. The group utilizes tactics such as drive-by downloads and FakeUpdates infections, facilitated by Mustard Tempest to gain initial access. Later, they use the BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. One of the events related to this incident involved a process running on the host `vnevado-win11t` using the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com`. The Process ID was 88.
question.question: There was another instance of a similar process being run on the same host in this incident. Can you identify the Process ID and the command line of this process?
solution: A user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96` was associated with suspicious activity linked to the Manatee Tempest cybercriminal group.

A process with Process ID `1332` used the command line `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com` on `2024-06-20t09:10:52.7298237z`, indicating possible interaction with a malicious domain associated with Manatee Tempest.

question.context: A suspicious WMI process creation was observed on the machine `vnevado-win11t`. Malware frequently uses WMI to spawn new processes, breaking process trees and further infecting a machine. On 2024-07-04, several commands were executed on the machine, including disabling recovery, deleting shadows, and using PowerShell to run a script. The investigation revealed some suspicious process creations.
question.question: What is the Azure Active Directory (AAD) Device ID of the host involved in this suspicious WMI process creation event?
solution: There was a suspicious WMI process creation on a machine with AadDeviceId `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e`.
The WMI process creation was associated with an account having SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`.

Attackers might be attempting to encrypt content on this device, rendering it unusable to users. This was part of a larger security incident that involved suspicious remote activity on the same machine, including attempts to initiate interactive sessions, modify files, pass WMI commands, create scheduled tasks, and other potentially malicious activities.

Attackers might be attempting to encrypt content on this device, rendering it unusable to users. For more information, refer to the Threat Analytics report: Threat overview: Human-operated ransomware.
question.question: Related to this alert, there was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT). What is the file name of the process that was used in this attempt?
solution: A ransomware payload was remotely launched on an account with the name `dp5hn`.
A possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected, involving the process with the filename `browsercore.exe`.

The possible incident occurred on July 4th, 2024, and was detected as a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is critical for Azure AD authentication. This anomaly suggests an attacker might be trying to move laterally or perform credential theft. Another related observation was a suspicious network event indicating possible lateral movement to another device.

The attempt to access the PRT originated from the host `vnevado-win11u`.
There is a possibility of lateral movement originating from the IP address `38.142.109.10` in close time proximity to the suspicious PRT access attempt.

question.context: A ransomware payload was remotely launched on the device `vnevado-win11u`. Attackers might be attempting to encrypt content on this device, rendering it unusable to users. Related to this incident, lateral movement activities have been detected on `Vnevado-jump` server using PSExec.
question.question: What is the name of the executable file used in the PSExec activity on `Vnevado-jump` server?
solution: A ransomware payload was remotely launched from IP address `99.83.111.100`.
PSExec was used to move laterally to the jump server `Vnevado-jump` with the file `notepad.exe`.

trajectory.action: SHOW TABLES

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessAccountName, FileName, FolderPath, ProcessCommandLine FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE DeviceName LIKE 'Vnevado-jump' AND (FileName LIKE '%psexec%' OR ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%psexec%' OR ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%PsExec%') ORDER BY Timestamp DESC LIMIT 50

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessAccountName, FileName, FolderPath, ProcessCommandLine FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE LOWER(DeviceName) = 'vnevado-jump' AND (LOWER(FileName) LIKE '%psexec%' OR LOWER(ProcessCommandLine) LIKE '%psexec%' OR LOWER(FileName) = 'psexesvc.exe') ORDER BY Timestamp DESC LIMIT 100

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessAccountName, FileName, FolderPath, ProcessCommandLine FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE LOWER(DeviceName)='vnevado-jump' AND (LOWER(ProcessCommandLine) LIKE '%psexesvc%' OR LOWER(ProcessCommandLine) LIKE '%\\\\\\\\%admin$%' OR LOWER(ProcessCommandLine) LIKE '%-accepteula%' OR LOWER(ProcessCommandLine) LIKE '%sc % start %' OR LOWER(FileName)='psexesvc.exe') ORDER BY Timestamp DESC LIMIT 200

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessAccountName, FileName, FolderPath, ProcessCommandLine FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE LOWER(DeviceName)='vnevado-jump' ORDER BY Timestamp DESC LIMIT 200

question.context: The identified suspicious activity on host `vnevado-win10r` involved attempts to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) tied to Azure AD authentication. The incident's timeline saw a triggering alert for a possible PRT access attempt using the process `browsercore.exe`.
question.question: What is the command line of the process that modified the LSASS process memory?
solution: There was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) using the process `browsercore.exe`.
The user with AadUserId `1d94aaf6-efe6-4e76-ad56-ffd7d1257bc1` was involved in a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT).

The LSASS process memory was modified using the command line `mimikatz.exe privilege::debug sekurlsa::pth /user:fk8mq /ntlm:96def1a633fc6790124d5f8fe21cc72b /domain:vnevado.alpineskihouse.co /run:..
otepad.exe //vnevado-jump cmd.exe` at `2024-06-20t09:03:47.538167z`, with Process ID `2020`.

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, ActionType, InitiatingProcessFileName, InitiatingProcessCommandLine, FileName, ProcessCommandLine, ReportId FROM DeviceEvents WHERE DeviceName = 'vnevado-win10r' AND (ActionType LIKE '%memory%' OR ActionType LIKE '%LSASS%' OR ActionType LIKE '%process tampering%' OR ActionType LIKE '%code injection%') AND (FileName = 'lsass.exe' OR InitiatingProcessFileName = 'lsass.exe' OR AdditionalFields LIKE '%lsass%' ) ORDER BY Timestamp ASC

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, ActionType, FileName, ProcessCommandLine, InitiatingProcessFileName, InitiatingProcessCommandLine, ReportId FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE DeviceName = 'vnevado-win10r' AND (ActionType LIKE '%memory%' OR ActionType LIKE '%injection%' OR ActionType LIKE '%handle%' OR ActionType LIKE '%tamper%') AND (ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%lsass.exe%' OR InitiatingProcessCommandLine LIKE '%lsass.exe%' OR FileName = 'lsass.exe' OR InitiatingProcessFileName = 'lsass.exe') ORDER BY Timestamp ASC

('2024-06-20 09:40:00.218287+00:00', '80a1b808-56fb-a977-ce72-b76acd95e64f', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Medium', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

question.context: A security incident involving multiple alerts reported by various entities. One of the alerts indicates the detection of active unknown malware that poses a significant threat as it can perform harmful actions and has persistence mechanisms in place.
question.question: What was the URL associated with the command and control behavior that was blocked?
solution: Active unknown malware was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
Lateral movement to the jump server was conducted using PSExec to IP address `99.83.111.100`.
Potentially compromised assets with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` exhibited ransomware-like behavior, impacting several devices.
A malicious command and control behavior directed to the URL `http://vectorsandarrows.com/` was blocked.

It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport'), ('2024-06-20 09:44:54.426426+00:00', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'Manatee Tempest activity group', 'High', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. question.context: To further investigate the incident, 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the targeted device. An attacker might be attempting to move laterally from another device on the network.
question.question: Can you identify the AadUserId of the account related to the CommandAndControl malware that was detected during lateral movement?
solution: Active malware was detected running or with persistence mechanisms on the machine associated with account `tgs2z` on `2024-07-04`.
Lateral movement detected using PSExec to the jump server at IP address `99.83.111.100` on `2024-07-10`.
Potential compromise and ransomware-like behavior detected on host with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033` on `2024-07-04`.
Command and control malware detected during lateral movement involving user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96` on `2024-07-04`.

trajectory.action: SHOW TABLES

SELECT 
  sa.AlertId,
  sa.Title,
  sa.Category,
  sa.Severity,
  sa.ThreatFamily,
  sa.Techniques,
  ae.EntityType,
  ae.AccountName,
  ae.AccountDomain,
  ae.AadUserId
FROM SecurityAlert sa
LEFT JOIN AlertEvidence ae ON ae.AlertId = sa.AlertId
WHERE (
    sa.Title LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR
    sa.Category LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR
    sa.ThreatFamily LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR
    sa.Description LIKE '%CommandAndControl%'
)
AND (
    sa.Title LIKE '%lateral%' OR
    sa.Description LIKE '%lateral%' OR
    sa.Category LIKE '%Lateral%' OR
    sa.Techniques LIKE '%lateral%'
)
ORDER BY sa.TimeGenerated DESC
LIMIT 50

SELECT 
  AlertId,
  Title,
  Categories,
  AttackTechniques,
  ThreatFamily,
  EntityType,
  AccountName,
  AccountDomain,
  AccountUpn,
  AccountObjectId AS AadUserId,
  DeviceName,
  TimeGenerated
FROM AlertEvidence
WHERE (
    ThreatFamily LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR
    Title LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR
    Categories LIKE '%CommandAndControl%'
)
AND (
    Title LIKE '%lateral%' OR
    Categories LIKE '%lateral%' OR
    AttackTechniques LIKE '%lateral%'
)
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC
LIMIT 50

question.context: The Manatee Tempest activity tracked by Microsoft is a notorious Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014, and involved in various malicious activities such as drive-by downloads and ransomware deployment. A recent incident associated with this group involved a suspicious HTTP request to `vectorsandarrows.com` from the IP address `198.43.121.209` using the command line: `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com`, with process ID 6460. Additionally, system recovery setting tampering with the command `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` was observed, likely to hinder recovery options in case of system corruption.
question.question: What is the process ID and the exact time when the `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` command was executed as part of the system recovery setting tampering?
solution: The account `dp5hn` is associated with activity from the Manatee Tempest cybercriminal group known for using tactics such as drive-by downloads, malvertising, and FakeUpdates to gain initial access.

A system recovery setting tampering attempt was detected with the command `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` executed by process ID `8136` on `2024-06-20t09:10:48.0438707z`, which might indicate an attempt to disable system recovery features on the device.

trajectory.action: SELECT table_name FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema = DATABASE()

SELECT Timestamp, ProcessId, InitiatingProcessId, InitiatingProcessCommandLine, FileName, ProcessCommandLine FROM DeviceProcessEvents WHERE ProcessCommandLine = 'bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no' OR InitiatingProcessCommandLine = 'bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no' ORDER BY Timestamp DESC LIMIT 50

question.context: A significant security incident involved potentially compromised assets exhibiting ransomware-like behavior. This impacted several devices where an attacker might be operating using a specific user account, IP, or device to move laterally across the network and infect as many devices as possible with ransomware. The automated remediation action might be taken to disable the account or device used by the attacker. One of the detected entities was IP address `99.83.111.100`, associated with the script `get-userprttoken.ps1` on the host `vnevado-win11t`.
question.question: Can you identify the URL associated with the blocked command and control behavior related to the malware infection?
solution: There are potentially compromised assets exhibiting ransomware-like behavior associated with the user account having SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`.
Command and Control (C2) behavior was blocked, linked to the URL `http://vectorsandarrows.com/`.

question.context: A security incident raised flags due to suspicious WMI process creation observed on a machine, which is indicative of possible malware activity. This was connected to a chain of processes including `get-userprttoken.ps1` and `curl` attempts. WMI is often utilized by malware to spawn new processes, breaking process trees and further infecting a machine.
question.question: In relation to the attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT), can you identify the name of the process involved in this activity?
solution: There was a suspicious WMI process creation by the user with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`.
There was a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) by a process with the extracted file name `browsercore.exe`.

question.context: On July 4, 2024, at 22:35:01, a security incident involving system recovery setting tampering was observed. The device `vnevado-win11t` with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033` was targeted. Command lines `vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all` and `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` were executed, which may indicate that adversaries attempted to stop or delete system recovery features to prevent recovering a corrupted system.
question.question: What is the IP address associated with the suspicious remote activity observed on this machine?
solution: The user account `dp5hn` was observed tampering with system recovery settings, possibly attempting to delete or disable recovery features.

Suspicious remote activity was detected from IP address `99.83.111.100`, which could indicate attempts to initiate interactive sessions, modify files, pass WMI commands, create scheduled tasks, or other malicious activities.

trajectory.action: SHOW TABLES

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, AadDeviceId, InitiatingProcessAccountName, FileName, ProcessCommandLine, ProcessId
FROM DeviceProcessEvents
WHERE AadDeviceId = 'e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033'
  AND Timestamp BETWEEN '2024-07-04 22:30:00' AND '2024-07-04 22:40:00'
  AND (
        ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all%'
        OR ProcessCommandLine LIKE '%bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no%'
      )
ORDER BY Timestamp
DESCRIBE DeviceProcessEvents

question.context: A recent security incident involved multiple attempts to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) which is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on various devices. During the investigation, it was observed that a suspicious activity attempted to access PRT from the account associated with the user `tgs2z`, possibly moving laterally within the organization. The IP address involved in this incident was `107.224.99.179`, and one of the processes noted was `powershell.exe`. This investigation further revealed a Command and Control (C2) behavior that was blocked.
question.question: What was the URL blocked due to Command and Control (C2) behavior in this incident?
solution: There was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) using the process `browsercore.exe`.
The account `dp5hn` was associated with a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT).
Command and Control behavior was detected and blocked for the URL `http://vectorsandarrows.com/`.

trajectory.action: SHOW TABLES

SELECT Timestamp, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessFileName, InitiatingProcessAccountUpn, InitiatingProcessAccountName, RemoteUrl, RemoteIP, ActionType, ReportId FROM DeviceNetworkEvents WHERE (RemoteIP = '107.224.99.179' OR InitiatingProcessAccountName = 'tgs2z' OR InitiatingProcessAccountUpn LIKE '%tgs2z%') AND (ActionType LIKE '%Block%' OR ActionType LIKE '%C2%' OR ActionType LIKE '%Command and Control%') ORDER BY Timestamp DESC LIMIT 50

SELECT sa.TimeGenerated, sa.AlertName, sa.Severity, ae.EntityType, ae.RemediationStatus, ae.RemoteUrl, ae.RemoteIP, ae.FileName, ae.AccountName, ae.AccountUpn, ae.AdditionalFields FROM SecurityAlert sa LEFT JOIN AlertEvidence ae ON sa.SystemAlertId = ae.SystemAlertId WHERE (ae.AccountName = 'tgs2z' OR ae.AccountUpn LIKE '%tgs2z%' OR ae.RemoteIP = '107.224.99.179' OR ae.FileName = 'powershell.exe' OR sa.AlertName LIKE '%Command and Control%' OR sa.Description LIKE '%Command and Control%' OR sa.Category LIKE '%Command and Control%' OR sa.AlertName LIKE '%C2%' OR sa.Description LIKE '%C2%' OR sa.Category LIKE '%C2%') ORDER BY sa.TimeGenerated DESC LIMIT 100
DESCRIBE SecurityAlert

question.context: During an investigation of a security incident, it was observed that 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the host `vnevado-win10r`, which might be an indication of an attacker attempting to move laterally from another network device. The process was initiated via the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com` with Process ID 1332. The incident is part of a larger campaign by the Manatee Tempest activity group, which is known for various cyber-attacks including the use of Cobalt Strike beacons for lateral movement and ransomware deployment.
question.question: As part of the Manatee Tempest activity group, what is the IP address associated with their activity in this incident?
solution: The 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on a device. An attacker might be attempting to move laterally to this device from another device on the network. The associated user account has the SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`.

Manatee Tempest, a Russia-based cybercriminal group active since June 2014, was identified. This group was responsible for the Dridex banking trojan and various other malvertising and infection methods. They have been observed partnering with Mustard Tempest to facilitate initial access. They use the IP address `198.43.121.209` for their activities.

question.context: An active unknown malware was detected, which assigned higher severity ratings due to its active state and potential persistence mechanisms. This malware was running on an unspecified host and included processes involving mimikatz.exe and cmd.exe, indicating credential theft activities. Following this malware detection, a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was identified, signifying that attackers could be trying to acquire this Azure AD authentication artifact to perform lateral movements or credential theft.
question.question: Can you identify the AadUserId associated with the possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT)?
solution: Active malware was detected on the host `vnevado-win10v`.
There was a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) using the process `browsercore.exe`.
The account with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96` was associated with a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT).

trajectory.action:
SELECT table_name 
FROM information_schema.tables 
WHERE table_schema = DATABASE()
  AND (table_name LIKE '%alert%' 
       OR table_name LIKE '%security%' 
       OR table_name LIKE '%azure%' 
       OR table_name LIKE '%aad%' 
       OR table_name LIKE '%signin%' 
       OR table_name LIKE '%event%' 
       OR table_name LIKE '%log%')
ORDER BY table_name

SELECT table_name 
FROM information_schema.tables 
WHERE table_schema = DATABASE()
ORDER BY table_name

SELECT a.TimeGenerated, a.AlertName, a.Description, a.SystemAlertId
FROM SecurityAlert a
WHERE a.AlertName LIKE '%PRT%' OR a.Description LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' OR a.Description LIKE '%PRT%'
ORDER BY a.TimeGenerated DESC

[('2024-06-20 09:44:54.286191+00:00', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

trajectory.action:
SELECT sa.TimeGenerated,
       sa.SystemAlertId,
       ae.EntityType,
       ae.AccountDisplayName,
       ae.AadUserId,
       ae.AccountSid,
       ae.AccountObjectId
FROM SecurityAlert sa
JOIN AlertEvidence ae
  ON ae.SystemAlertId = sa.SystemAlertId
WHERE sa.AlertName = 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)'
  AND (ae.AadUserId IS NOT NULL OR ae.AccountObjectId IS NOT NULL)
ORDER BY sa.TimeGenerated DESC

SELECT COLUMN_NAME
FROM information_schema.COLUMNS
WHERE TABLE_SCHEMA = DATABASE()
  AND TABLE_NAME = 'AlertEvidence'
ORDER BY ORDINAL_POSITION

SELECT sa.SystemAlertId,
       sa.TimeGenerated,
       ae.EntityType,
       ae.AccountName,
       ae.AccountDomain,
       ae.AccountUpn,
       ae.AccountObjectId
FROM SecurityAlert sa
JOIN AlertEvidence ae
  ON ae.AlertId = sa.SystemAlertId
WHERE sa.AlertName = 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)'
  AND ae.AccountObjectId IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY sa.TimeGenerated DESC

SELECT TimeGenerated, ActivityType, ResultDescription, AadUserId, UserPrincipalName, DeviceId
FROM IdentityLogonEvents
WHERE ActivityType LIKE '%PRT%' 
   OR ResultDescription LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' 
   OR ResultDescription LIKE '%PRT%'
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC

SELECT COLUMN_NAME
FROM information_schema.COLUMNS
WHERE TABLE_SCHEMA = DATABASE()
  AND TABLE_NAME = 'IdentityLogonEvents'
ORDER BY ORDINAL_POSITION

SELECT TimeGenerated,
       ActionType,
       Application,
       FailureReason,
       AccountUpn,
       AccountObjectId AS AadUserId
FROM IdentityLogonEvents
WHERE ActionType LIKE '%PRT%'
   OR FailureReason LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' OR FailureReason LIKE '%PRT%'
   OR Application LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' OR Application LIKE '%PRT%'
   OR AdditionalFields LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' OR AdditionalFields LIKE '%PRT%'
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC

SELECT TimeGenerated, UserPrincipalName, AadUserId
FROM AADNonInteractiveUserSignInLogs
WHERE (ResultDescription LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%' OR ResultDescription LIKE '%PRT%' 
       OR ConditionalAccessStatus LIKE '%PRT%' 
       OR AdditionalFields LIKE '%PRT%' OR AdditionalFields LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%')
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC

SELECT COLUMN_NAME
FROM information_schema.COLUMNS
WHERE TABLE_SCHEMA = DATABASE()
  AND TABLE_NAME = 'AADNonInteractiveUserSignInLogs'
ORDER BY ORDINAL_POSITION

SELECT TimeGenerated, UserPrincipalName, UserId AS AadUserId
FROM AADNonInteractiveUserSignInLogs
WHERE ResultDescription LIKE '%Primary Refresh Token%'
   OR ResultDescription LIKE '%PRT%'
   OR ConditionalAccessStatus LIKE '%PRT%'
   OR AuthenticationDetails LIKE '%PRT%'
   OR AuthenticationProcessingDetails LIKE '%PRT%'
   OR Status LIKE '%PRT%'
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC

SELECT COLUMN_NAME
FROM information_schema.COLUMNS
WHERE TABLE_SCHEMA = DATABASE()
  AND TABLE_NAME = 'SecurityAlert'
ORDER BY ORDINAL_POSITION

SELECT
  TimeGenerated,
  SystemAlertId,
  Entities
FROM SecurityAlert
WHERE AlertName = 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)'
ORDER BY TimeGenerated DESC

question.context: A security incident involving system recovery setting tampering was observed on the device with name `vnevado-win10r`. The incident involved processes `vssblatemp.exe` and `bcdedit.exe` being executed on the host `vnevado-win10r` to potentially disrupt recovery options. Additionally, suspicious hands-on keyboard user behavior was detected around the same time, which might indicate that the user has been compromised.
question.question: Following these activities, there was an indication of ransomware behavior detected in the file system on a device. Can you determine the AadDeviceId of the host where this ransomware activity was detected?
solution: The account `dp5hn` was responsible for tampering with system recovery settings.
The same host device with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033` exhibited suspicious hands-on keyboard behavior, indicating a potential user compromise.
Ransomware behavior was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`, indicating potential mass encryption of files by ransomware.

A Windows Sysinternals tool was renamed to `mimikatz.exe` and then launched, which might indicate malicious activity.

question.context: In this investigation, there is a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) that was detected as part of this incident. This is related to Azure AD authentication security threats.
question.question: What is the Azure Active Directory (AAD) device ID of the host where the possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected?
solution: All file snapshots and shadow copies have been deleted via WMI or VSSAdmin using the account with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`, which is a common tactic during Ransomware infection.
A possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected on the host with AadDeviceId `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e`.

[('2024-06-20 09:00:03.183652+00:00', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

question.context: A security incident involving multiple malicious activities was detected. It started with a known credential theft tool, `mimikatz.exe`, being executed at two different times, indicating an attempt to dump users' credentials. This activity led to lateral movement attempts to the jump server and suspicious remote activities on the machine. Subsequent analysis revealed command and control behavior of malware which was blocked.
question.question: What was the URL associated with the command and control behavior detected in the end alert?
solution: A known credential theft tool execution was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
There was lateral movement to the jump server from the IP address `99.83.111.100` using PSExec.
Suspicious remote activity was observed on the account `dp5hn`.
Command and Control behavior was blocked for the URL `http://vectorsandarrows.com/`.

question.context: A potential security incident involving a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected. A file `browsercore.exe` was launched on the host `vnevado-win11t` by an account with the name `dp5hn` and SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`. The process ID for this event was `7036`. This activity may have been an attempt by attackers to access the PRT to move laterally within the organization or perform credential theft. The Primary Refresh Token is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on various platforms and is essential for single sign-on (SSO) across applications.
question.question: Can you identify the AadDeviceId related to this alert?
solution: A possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`.

question.context: During a recent security investigation, it was found that a malicious credential theft tool `mimikatz.exe` was executed with the process ID 4464 on 2024-06-20 at 09:03:04.6442161, originating from IP address `107.224.99.179`. The command line included attempts to leverage credentials from the domain `vnevado.alpineskihouse.co`. This execution was flagged on 2024-07-04 at 22:35:03.869406+00:00 for its intent to dump user credentials. Subsequently, there was a lateral movement attempt to the jump server `Vnevado-jump` on 2024-07-10 at 11:24:45.260113+00:00.
question.question: During this investigation, a potentially compromised user account was identified. Can you provide the SID of the user account that may be operating with ransomware-like behavior?
solution: A known credential theft tool execution command was detected on the account with the name `tgs2z`.

question.context: A security incident involving an attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected. The PRT is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on various devices, including Windows 10. The incident involved a device with HostName `vnevado-win10s` and AadDeviceId `f5b847aa-8712-4bf6-b4f7-ed6cd89e1505`, where the process `browsercore.exe` (ProcessId `2676` created at `2024-06-20T09:10:59.867384Z`) was running. Attackers may use this to move laterally within the organization.
question.question: Following this incident, 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on another device during lateral movement. What is the AadDeviceId of this affected device?
solution: A possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected for the user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the device with AadDeviceId `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e`, indicating an attempt of lateral movement.

SELECT di.AadDeviceId
FROM SecurityAlert sa
LEFT JOIN AlertEvidence ae ON ae.AlertId = sa.SystemAlertId OR ae.AlertId = sa.AlertId
LEFT JOIN DeviceInfo di ON di.DeviceId = ae.DeviceId OR di.DeviceName = ae.DeviceName
WHERE (sa.Tactics LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR sa.DisplayName LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR sa.Description LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR sa.AlertName LIKE '%CommandAndControl%')
  AND sa.TimeGenerated >= '2024-06-20T09:10:59'
ORDER BY sa.TimeGenerated ASC
LIMIT 10

SELECT DISTINCT di.AadDeviceId
FROM SecurityIncident si
JOIN AlertEvidence ae ON FIND_IN_SET(ae.AlertId, REPLACE(REPLACE(si.AlertIds, '[', ''), ']', '')) > 0
LEFT JOIN DeviceInfo di ON di.DeviceId = ae.DeviceId OR di.DeviceName = ae.DeviceName
WHERE si.TimeGenerated >= '2024-06-20T09:10:59.867384Z'
  AND (si.Title LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR si.Description LIKE '%CommandAndControl%' OR si.IncidentName LIKE '%CommandAndControl%')
LIMIT 10

question.context: A security incident was detected involving suspicious 'GenRansom' behavior on the host 'vnevado-win11t'. This malware can perform harmful actions and spread across machines. The active malware was found running or having persistence mechanisms in place, necessitating urgent precautionary measures. Following this, a system recovery setting tampering alert was observed on the device, where adversaries might be disabling recovery features using native Windows utilities.
question.question: There was suspicious remote activity involving this malware incident. Can you identify the AadDeviceId of the host involved in this suspicious remote activity?
solution: Suspicious 'GenRansom' behavior was detected on device with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`.
System recovery setting tampering was observed with the process `vssblatemp.exe`.
Suspicious remote activity was detected on device with AadDeviceId `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e`.
